sen.j: 山伏（やまぶし）とは、山の中をひたすら歩き、修行をする修験道の行者。
sen.e: Yamabushi is a practitioner of Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts) who earnestly walks in mountains as ascetic practices.
Yamabushi is a practitioner of Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism/shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts) who earnestly walks in the mountains as an ascetic practice.

sen.j: 「修験者」（しゅげんじゃ）とも言う。
基本的に霊山と呼ばれる大山 (鳥取県)や羽黒山 (山形県)などの奥深い山中で、踏破（抖擻）や懺悔などの厳しい艱難苦行を行なって、山岳が持つ自然の霊力を身に付ける事を目的とする。
sen.e: Their basic object is to earn natural spiritual power of mountains by practicing severe hardships such as Toha (Toso) (running throughout mountains) and Zange (confession) in deep sacred mountains, such as Daisen Mountain (Tottori Prefecture) and Haguro-yama Mountain (Yamagata Prefecture).

sen.j: 頭に頭巾（ときん）と呼ばれる多角形の小さな帽子のような物を付け、手には錫杖（しゃくじょう）と呼ばれる金属製の杖を持つ。
sen.e: They put on polygonal hat-like object called Tokin on their heads, and hold metallic cane called Shakujo in their hands.
The practitioner wears a polygonal hat-like object called a Tokin on his head, and holds a metallic cane called a Shakujo in his hands.

sen.j: 袈裟と、篠懸（すずかけ）と言う麻 (繊維)の法衣を身に纏う。
sen.e: They put on kesa (Buddhist stole) and suzukake, which is a clerical garment made from hemp.

sen.j: 山中での互いの連絡や合図のために、ホラガイを加工した楽器や護身用に刀を持つ。
sen.e: They carry instruments made out from conch shell for communicating each others in mountains, and also carry Japanese sword for their protection.

sen.j: 天狗や烏天狗は、山伏の装束を身に纏う。
sen.e: Tengu (long-nosed goblin) and Karasu Tengu (crow-billed goblin) wear Yamabushi's costumes.

sen.j: 山伏独特の修験十六道具は、それぞれ不二の世界、十界、不動明王、母胎などを象徴する。
sen.e: 16 tools of Shugen each represents this only one world, Jikkai (the Ten Realms), mother's womb, and so on.

sen.j: 羽黒山 (山形県)では毎年9月、希望者が白装束を着て入峰し、断食、滝打ち、火渡り、床堅（座禅）、忍苦の行（南蛮いぶし）などの活動を通して山伏修行を体験できる。
sen.e: In Haguro-yama Mountain (Yamagata Prefecture), an applicant can wear white costume and enter mountain, experiencing Yamabushi's ascetic practices such as fasting, Takiuchi (standing under waterfall), walking over fire, Ninku no Gyo (Nanban Ibushi, or being smoked), and so on, in September of every year.
